Which tokens can I stake on Vista? Currently, the only tokens that can be staked are: - $BONZI : The mascot and first meme deployed on Ethervista. - $VISTA : The native token of Ethervista. Where can I stake these tokens? - Hardstake for $VISTA → Available on ethervista.app . - Hardstake for $BONZI → Available on bonzivista.app . What’s the difference between Hardstake and Hardlock? - Hardlock : A double-sided staking protocol, requiring an equal amount of $VISTA + $ETH or $BONZI + $ETH . The stake is permanently locked LP but provides permanent yield. The main benefit is higher yield compared to Hardstake. - Hardstake : A single-sided staking protocol with a 14-day lock period. It offers a lower yield than Hardlock but allows users to unstake anytime after the lock period. Which do you recommend: Hardstake or Hardlock? - Hardlock → Higher rewards but permanent LP lock. - Hardstake → Easier and more flexible. Ideal for long-term holders who may want to sell at peak prices. How do I add to the liquidity pool? Follow these steps: ➡️ For $VISTA : 1) Visit ethervista.app > Stake > Hardlock > Add to LP ➡️ For $BONZI : 1) Visit ethervista.app > Stake > Hardlock > Add to LP 2) Visit bonzivista.app > Finance > Add your LP tokens

**Q:** @Freedom_john could you share that simulation here, please?
**A:** Fair point, at first glance Vista does feel a bit like Uniswap — you provide liquidity, earn yield, like almost every DEX. But the mechanics are actually pretty different. Uniswap LPs earn fees too, but rewards are pooled and split per trade, so you’ve got impermanent loss, MEV risk, and zero alignment with the token itself — $UNI doesn’t benefit from usage unless governance decides to turn on a fee switch (which still hasn’t happened). With Vista, there’s no fee switch. The protocol auto-distributes ETH to stakers and LPs using the Euler model — a kind of on-chain ledger that tracks exactly how much ETH you’re owed based on your position. It’s efficient, predictable, and requires no new token emissions. Regaeding burning mechanism, Vista actually burns with every trade. So the more the protocol is used, the scarcer it becomes. No need for buybacks or off-chain interventions. You can check It here:
*— LuxAEterna*

**Q:** How to stake vista
**A:** 🚀 Getting Started with Staking ➡️ For $VISTA : 1. Buy $VISTA on ethervista.app . 2. Visit ethervista.app . 3. Navigate to Finance and stake your tokens. ➡️ For $BONZI : 1. Buy $BONZI on ethervista.app . 2. Visit bonzivista.app . 3. Open Finance (desktop only) and stake your tokens. Can I access Finance on my phone? No, it is currently desktop only. Which tokens can I stake on Vista? Currently, the only tokens that can be staked are: - $BONZI : The mascot and first meme deployed on Ethervista. - $VISTA : The native token of Ethervista. Where can I stake these tokens? - Hardstake for $VISTA → Available on ethervista.app . - Hardstake for $BONZI → Available on bonzivista.app . What’s the difference between Hardstake and Hardlock? - Hardlock : A double-sided staking protocol, requiring an equal amount of $VISTA + $ETH or $BONZI + $ETH . The stake is permanently locked LP but provides permanent yield. The main benefit is higher yield compared to Hardstake. - Hardstake : A single-sided staking protocol with a 14-day lock period. It offers a lower yield than Hardlock but allows users to unstake anytime after the lock period. Which do you recommend: Hardstake or Hardlock? - Hardlock → Higher rewards but permanent LP lock. - Hardstake → Easier and more flexible. Ideal for long-term holders who may want to sell at peak prices. How do I add to the liquidity pool? Follow these steps: ➡️ For $VISTA : 1) Visit ethervista.app > Stake > Hardlock > Add to LP ➡️ For $BONZI : 1) Visit ethervista.app > Stake > Hardlock > Add to LP 2) Visit bonzivista.app > Finance > Add your LP tokens

**Q:** Hi, could someone explain to me what the difference is between Eulend, Hardstake, and Hardlock? I read about it on Ethevista’s website, but I still found it confusing.
**A:** 🚀 Getting Started with Staking ➡️ For $VISTA : 1. Buy $VISTA on ethervista.app . 2. Visit ethervista.app . 3. Navigate to Finance and stake your tokens. ➡️ For $BONZI : 1. Buy $BONZI on ethervista.app . 2. Visit bonzivista.app . 3. Open Finance (desktop only) and stake your tokens. Can I access Finance on my phone? No, it is currently desktop only. Which tokens can I stake on Vista? Currently, the only tokens that can be staked are: - $BONZI : The mascot and first meme deployed on Ethervista. - $VISTA : The native token of Ethervista. Where can I stake these tokens? - Hardstake for $VISTA → Available on ethervista.app . - Hardstake for $BONZI → Available on bonzivista.app . What’s the difference between Hardstake and Hardlock? - Hardlock : A double-sided staking protocol, requiring an equal amount of $VISTA + $ETH or $BONZI + $ETH . The stake is permanently locked LP but provides permanent yield. The main benefit is higher yield compared to Hardstake. - Hardstake : A single-sided staking protocol with a 14-day lock period. It offers a lower yield than Hardlock but allows users to unstake anytime after the lock period. Which do you recommend: Hardstake or Hardlock? - Hardlock → Higher rewards but permanent LP lock. - Hardstake → Easier and more flexible. Ideal for long-term holders who may want to sell at peak prices. How do I add to the liquidity pool? Follow these steps: ➡️ For $VISTA : 1) Visit ethervista.app > Stake > Hardlock > Add to LP ➡️ For $BONZI : 1) Visit ethervista.app > Stake > Hardlock > Add to LP 2) Visit bonzivista.app > Finance > Add your LP tokens
*— Combot*

**205.** The VISTA token, from the Ethervista platform, works as a deflationary token with a fixed supply of 1 million units and was created to operate on a decentralized exchange (DEX) on the Ethereum network. Ethervista aims to increase the security of token releases and reduce risks by implementing mandatory five-day liquidity locks for new tokens, which helps avoid “rug pulls” (abrupt liquidity withdrawals) common on similar platforms. In addition, transaction fees in VISTA are partially directed to token burning, which reduces total supply and increases scarcity, encouraging appreciation over time. Ethervista also differentiates itself by using a rate structure in native ETH and by distributing these rates between liquidity providers and token creators, strengthening the ecosystem. The goal is to encourage token retention and create long-term value for participants, attracting memecoin projects and other assets on the Ethereum blockchain. However, because it is a new platform and with contracts not yet audited, the use requires caution due to possible security risks...

**2097.** You can stake on the website itself (see the address on the official X profile), in the top menu there are the Stake options. From what I understand, it is not possible to know the APR in advance because Ethervista uses the Euler model for staking Rewards. Basically, your Rewards will be the amount you staked times the difference between the Euler number when you claimed your Rewards and the Euler number when you staked. This Euler number is calculated every time there is a transaction: Current Euler = Previous Euler * transaction fee/total staked liquidity.

**2354.** 1. Revenue Model Uniswap and Other DEXs: - Liquidity providers (LPs) earn rewards from token inflation (e.g., $UNI ), which dilutes value over time. - Token creators must sell their holdings to profit, potentially causing sell pressure and harming token value. Ethervista: - Rewards LPs and token creators in ETH, a stable and high-value asset, avoiding token inflation. - Creators can set customizable protocol fees (e.g., $7 per swap), earning ETH directly without selling tokens, enabling sustainable monetization. - Locks liquidity for 5 days, reducing rug pull risks and offering long-term trust mechanisms.

**2355.** 2. Community Incentives Uniswap: - Focuses on short-term liquidity with no emphasis on community building. - Lacks mechanisms to engage and reward users for long-term participation. Ethervista: - Incentivizes community-driven growth with ETH rewards for LPs and stakers. - Encourages LP locking, creating a virtuous cycle: Locked liquidity → Higher user trust → Increased trading volume → More ETH rewards.

**2356.** 3. Security and Rug Pull Prevention Uniswap: - Does not enforce liquidity locks, leaving projects vulnerable to rug pulls. - Token creators can remove liquidity at any time without penalties. Ethervista: - Enforces a 5-day liquidity lock, giving users time to evaluate project legitimacy. - Introduces a Hardlock option, enabling creators to permanently lock liquidity while still earning ETH rewards. 4. Regulatory Safety Uniswap: - Token-based rewards risk classification as securities, creating potential legal issues. - Limited mechanisms to address compliance concerns. Ethervista: - Pays rewards and fees in ETH, avoiding token inflation and mitigating the risk of regulatory scrutiny. 5. Advanced DeFi Features Uniswap: - Limited innovation beyond basic swap and liquidity pool functionality. - Rewards structure favors short-term incentives. Ethervista: - Pioneers the Euler Model, a scalable and efficient reward distribution system. - Plans for advanced tools like feeless flash loans, lending, and futures trading. - Supports token creators with features like customizable fees and ETH-based staking rewards.

**2710.** Major crypto exchange cancels USDT and 9 other currencies due to European law Major crypto exchange cancels USDT and 9 other currencies due to European law Photo: 4kclips/Shutterstock The consequences of the new European crypto law, Markets in Crypto-Assets Regulation (MiCA), are noticeable. The major crypto exchange Crypto.com will cancel ten tokens on January 31 to comply with this new European law. For example, Tether (USDT) will soon disappear from this exchange. Why is Crypto.com scrapping USDT? Crypto service providers within the European Union are known as 'CASPs'. This stands for 'crypto asset service providers'. These companies are licensed to offer crypto assets. The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA) is requesting CASPs to remove stablecoins that do not comply with MiCA legislation from their offering. The MiCA is a new European law that should make the crypto market safer and more transparent. The law was signed in June 2023. Its introduction will take place step by step. Most of the legislation came into effect on December 31, 2024. To comply with MiCA legislation, Crypto.com is removing the following ten tokens: USDT Dai (DAI) Wrapped Bitcoin (WBTC) Liquid Cro (LCRO) XSGD (XSGD) PayPal USD (PYUSD) Pax Dollar (PAX) Pax Gold (PAXG) Crypto.com Staked ETH (CDCETH) Crypto.com Staked SOL (CDCSOL)

**2711.** Users have until March 31 to convert their tokens into MiCA-compliant assets. If this does not happen, “the tokens will be automatically converted to a compliant stablecoin or a token with a comparable market value,” a Crypto.com spokesperson said. USDT is also no longer available on Bitvavo and Coinbase USDT currently has a market capitalization of $139 billion, making it by far the largest stablecoin on the market. However, some parties express their concerns about the transparency of Tether, the company behind USDT. Juan Ignacio Ibañez, Member of the Technical Committee of the MiCA Crypto Alliance, has a clear message: “No trace of USDT should remain by March 31, even in 'sell-only' mode.” Crypto.com is not the first exchange to cancel USDT. This stablecoin has previously disappeared from exchanges such as Coinbase because it does not comply with EU legislation. Coinbase customers were allowed to convert USDT to MiCA-compliant stablecoins, such as USD Coin (USDC). This token currently has a market capitalization of $52 billion. Bitvavo also recently took the decision to stop USDT because the Dutch exchange wants to comply with European rules

**2992.** Ethervista’s Unique Euler Model Explained 💡 At Ethervista, we’re setting a new standard with the Euler Model—a groundbreaking way to distribute rewards in ETH, NOT depreciating tokens. How It Works: Instead of complex token rewards, the Euler Model tracks a rising sequence of values (Euler amounts) updated every transaction. Each liquidity provider (LP) has a baseline (Euler0) recorded when they enter. Their rewards are calculated using a simple formula: 📊Rewards = LP Share × (Current Euler – Euler0) This eliminates high gas fees, scales efficiently to millions of users, and ensures fair, tamper-proof ETH rewards. ✨ Why It’s a Game-Changer: ✅ LPs earn ETH directly from swap fees ✅ Hardstaking & Hardlocking let users & creators earn ETH passively ✅ Negligible gas costs for mass adoption With zero unnecessary tokens and pure ETH rewards, Ethervista is leading DeFi innovation.

**3045.** How traditional DeFi Yield Farms failed No Real Revenue Model – Most farms rely on new deposits instead of generating sustainable revenue. Without external income, payouts collapse when new users stop joining. High APYs = High Inflation = Death Spiral – Yield farms print massive amounts of tokens, causing oversupply. Farmers dump rewards, crashing the token price and making APYs meaningless. Unsustainable Liquidity Mining – Liquidity mining attracts short-term "mercenary capital" that leaves once rewards decrease. This creates temporary TVL without long-term stability. No Utility for the Farm Token – If the farm token has no real use, it turns into a farm-and-dump scheme. Once demand drops, the token becomes worthless. Hidden Ponzinomics in Staking – Many farms recycle rewards into staking loops to create an illusion of sustainability. This only lasts as long as new liquidity flows in. Team & Whale Exit Liquidity – Insiders farm and dump before retail investors realize what’s happening. When the team exits, the farm collapses. Spotting a DeFi Ponzi – Look for no real revenue, unrealistic APYs, and a heavy reliance on new users. If rewards come only from inflation, it’s a Ponzi in disguise.

Traditional protocols like Lido, Rocket Pool, and native staking systems (Cardano, Polkadot, Cosmos) are based on validator rewards and inflationary models. Their APRs range between 3–6% because the underlying asset (e.g. $ETH , $ADA ) distributes yield proportionally to massive validator sets. These systems are secure but diluted—designed more for network integrity than user profit. Fee-based protocols, on the other hand, often advertise higher returns, but most of them distribute platform revenue (trading or lending fees) across millions of dollars in TVL, resulting in APR rates under 8% unless leveraged. The more users that stake, the thinner the rewards. Even innovative protocols like Pendle or Aave distribute real revenue, but they’re competing with massive capital and complex mechanisms—so yield is stable but low. Ethervista is one of the few systems offering real-yield in $ETH without relying on token inflation or emissions.

**3324.** TL;DR To keep things clean, I have designed a pocket Q&A for you that underlines the strategy of ethervista. Hype alone is not how projects succeed, and especially not with genuine product development, it is foremost not ethical to market if things are not ready. Therefore first focus is building a userbase. This happens person to person. Which is a slow but significant way of seeking Market-fit. Once there is enough Market-fit. Market-ing will follow naturally. (This is proven over and over, ask GPT if you dont believe me 😉 ) So the main question we hear Is Ethervista dead? The project is quietly growing without paid marketing. Unlike VC-funded projects, Ethervista distributed over $1M in ETH rewards with zero token emissions — proving the Euler Model works. Building in stealth is normal in DeFi. -- Why doesn't Ethervista use marketing like other tokens? Because as explained earlier, it contradicts DeFi ethos. Paid listings, launchpads, and presales that co-exist with the marketing you are familiar with all create early sell pressure and rug potential. Ethervista flipped that by launching with a real product and fee-based yield. Where activities are funded the more Vista is traded. Also the team has chosen very clearly to balance Under-promise, over-deliver. As to not inflate the intrinsic value of the ecosystem, aiming to grow by network-effect. Just like Bitcoin did. - Is there proof the model works? Yes — over $1M in ETH distributed to BONZI and VISTA holders. Plus, VISTA outperformed Uniswap in many metrics. Meanwhile, Uniswap is leaking more bags than an airport carousel. That is not insignificant. And is known by various developers that consider to use ethervista's smartcontracts. Is the Euler Model useful beyond yield? Yes — especially in GameFi. It supports gradual progression, symbiosis, and adaptive scaling without token inflation. Great for DAOs, games, and DeFi-native experiments. Think of it as slow finance, not no finance. We noticed a growing interest from dev to apply euler model into game theory. Ambientagi is most known (see agent gamifications) But there are others! Not yet known —- Could this work on Solana too? In theory, yes. But bridging $VISTA to Solana needs robust liquidity and router adaptations. Neon EVM might make this feasible soon. Cross-chain chaos, now with less chaos. Why is organic growth better? Because real users > fake volume. Bitcoin did the same. Hype fades, utility scales. This has been endorsed by all major influencers. Is there a roadmap? The roadmap evolves as problems arise or liquidity returns. Vista does not fix itself to 1 route and keeps itself ready to adapt to changes in the market of DeFi. However there are a few distinct directions that do take place. Short term: Expand to other high liquidity networks making ethervista compatible with all significant DeFi blockchains Long term To design a sustainable revenue stream for token creators and To distribute the fees from trading to all token holders in a fair way (See Euler model). See it as the Coop of DeFi. Where everyone becomes a shareholder and depending on their stake they can benefit from the profits made by trading on ethervista DEX without causing sell pressure on tokens. Unlike CEX where all fees go to the house, or Uniswap where all LP rewards are paid in tokens.

**3341.** Ethereum developers activated the Pectra upgrade at epoch 364032, around 6:05 a.m. ET on Wednesday, marking the network's biggest update since The Merge in 2022. Pectra introduces 11 Ethereum Improvement Proposals focused on boosting staking efficiency, user experience, validator operations, and Layer 2 scalability. After early testnet issues, including Holesky validator misconfigurations, the March 2025 Hoodi deployment cleared the path for Pectra's mainnet launch. Among Pectra's various improvements, EIP-7702 pushes account abstraction forward by enabling smart contract logic in wallets and gasless transactions. EIP-7251 raises the maximum validator cap from 32 ETH to 2,048 ETH, allowing large stakers to consolidate and streamline operations. Building on Ethereum's Dencun upgrade of March 2024, which introduced proto-danksharding via EIP-4844, EIP-7691 doubles temporary data storage blob throughput to make Layer 2 rollups faster and cheaper as demand surges. Pectra also slashes validator onboarding time, makes key historical data accessible onchain, and lays the groundwork for future upgrades like Fusaka .

**3435.** What is the difference between Hardstake and Hardlock? - Hardlock: A two-sided staking protocol, which requires the same amount of $VISTA + $ETH or $BONZI + $ETH . The stake is permanently locked in LP (except for Vista), but offers permanent yield. The main benefit is a higher yield compared to Hardstake. - Hardstake: A one-sided staking protocol with a 14-day lock-up period. Offers a lower yield than Hardlock, but allows users to deactivate staking at any time after the lock-up period.

**3609.** Fair point, at first glance Vista does feel a bit like Uniswap — you provide liquidity, earn yield, like almost every DEX. But the mechanics are actually pretty different. Uniswap LPs earn fees too, but rewards are pooled and split per trade, so you’ve got impermanent loss, MEV risk, and zero alignment with the token itself — $UNI doesn’t benefit from usage unless governance decides to turn on a fee switch (which still hasn’t happened). With Vista, there’s no fee switch. The protocol auto-distributes ETH to stakers and LPs using the Euler model — a kind of on-chain ledger that tracks exactly how much ETH you’re owed based on your position. It’s efficient, predictable, and requires no new token emissions. Regaeding burning mechanism, Vista actually burns with every trade. So the more the protocol is used, the scarcer it becomes. **4035.** ⚡️Eulend Recap + What’s Next? Eulend has redefined lending and liquidity provision in DeFi, bringing a fresh approach to how ETH and stablecoins work together in the Ethervista ecosystem. Let’s revisit its unmatched benefits and take a look at the road ahead. Why Eulend Stands Out: - Single-Sided Liquidity, Optimized Profitability: With idle Ethereum or stablecoins, you can now earn ETH without the complexity of traditional dual-sided LPing. Provide ETH, and it’s automatically paired 1:1 with USDC or USDT from borrowers. The paired assets generate LP fees and protocol fees from the ETH/USDC or ETH/USDT pools. Unlike traditional LPs, ETH lenders on Eulend earn from all lending pools simultaneously, amplifying profitability while keeping liquidity provision simple. - Borrowers Earn, Too: Borrowers provide only stablecoins like USDT or USDC, avoiding the need to contribute ETH. Not only do they maintain their token holdings, but they also earn 60% of the LP rewards generated by the shared pools, creating a system where borrowing becomes highly incentivized and profitable. - Unmatched Flexibility with Feeless Flashloans: Any ETH not yet paired with stablecoins is available for feeless flashloans. This unique feature puts idle ETH to productive use, benefiting borrowers, arbitrageurs, and the ecosystem as a whole by enhancing trading efficiency. The Impact So Far: In just 4 days: $50,000+ in stablecoins borrowed. 15+ ETH provided by lenders. What’s Next for Eulend? - Scaling Liquidity for Lower Trading Costs: As more lenders and borrowers join Eulend, the system creates even deeper liquidity pools. This makes Ethervista the go-to DEX for affordable stablecoin swaps. In fact, thanks to our flat-fee model, trades of $2,000+ are already cheaper than Uniswap. - Expanding Token Pairs: We’re working to introduce popular tokens like wBTC and memecoins to Eulend, responding to community demand. This expansion will unlock more opportunities for lenders and borrowers while driving liquidity to the broader Ethervista ecosystem. The Bigger Picture: Eulend isn’t just another lending protocol—it’s the next step in Ethervista’s mission to revolutionize DeFi. By combining single-sided liquidity, incentivized borrowing, and seamless access to LP fees, Eulend ensures every ETH or stablecoin holder can participate in building a sustainable, collaborative, and profitable ecosystem

Central to the lean startup methodology is the assumption that when startup companies invest their time into iteratively building products or services to meet the needs of early customers, the company can reduce market risks and sidestep the need for large amounts of initial project funding and expensive product launches and financial failures. Historical secular bull markets (like the 1980s-2000 tech boom) lasted 15-20 years, but each cycle is different. The pattern suggests technology revolutions unfold in waves: first infrastructure (chips, cloud, middleware), then applications. We're arguably still in the infrastructure phase. If AI proves as transformative as predicted, the application layer could drive a second wave of growth—though this remains unproven. However, "bear markets within secular bulls" can be severe. The S&P 500 has experienced drawdowns exceeding 50% historically (1929-1932: -86%; 2007-2009: -57%). The Nasdaq fell 78% during the dot-com crash (2000-2002). Assuming protection at 50% is dangerous. Long-term market growth requires caveats. U.S. equities have grown over the long term due to productivity gains, earnings growth, and survivorship bias—but this isn't universal. Japan's Nikkei took 34 years to recover its 1989 peak. Timing, valuation, and geography matter enormously. The Bitcoin/crypto comparison is weaker. Unlike the S&P 500, which represents productive enterprises generating earnings, Bitcoin and cryptocurrencies lack fundamental cash flows. Their value proposition (scarcity, decentralization) is different from equities. The 15-year history of crypto provides insufficient data to claim it will behave like centuries of equity markets. The AI application layer opportunity is real but speculative. Small-cap AI startups haven't seen their "bubble moment" yet—true. But remember: most dot-com companies failed. Key Updates: 1) External V2 Contract Audit This Week: The new token contract is finalized and will undergo security audits by Hacken starting Wednesday. These enhancements are designed to provide a better experience and greater value for all $OPSEC holders. 3) Token Migration for DEX & CEX holders ( READ ME ⚠️) 👉 For those using DEX platforms (Trust Wallet, MetaMask, Uniswap, Ledger, Trezor, etc..), please send your V1 tokens to the official V2 recovery address: 0x362538c16a2868038AE72B608c080B6433f979C9 👉 For CEX platform users (BingX, CoinEX), please await further instructions. We are coordinating with these exchanges to ensure a seamless transition. Practically: OpSec sends the V2 tokens and CEX's send V1 back. 4) Distribution Plan: After thorough discussions, we have decided on a claim-based distribution method. This approach offers several advantages: - Reduces gas fees for the team, allowing us to reinvest those funds into the community. Minimizes the risk of exploits and scams. - Spreads out sell pressure, preventing a sudden drop in price. - An eligibility form will be posted on CloudVerse, allowing users to check their claim status and ensure they receive their V2 tokens securely. CAUTION: We Don't Do Airdrops 🚫🚫🚫🚫 5) Market Strategy: The first few days post-relaunch are crucial. We need to show strength to regain trust and maintain a positive momentum. The recent market trends and upcoming ETF launches suggest a bullish market, which could positively impact our relaunch. ❇️ RECAP Action Needed: - DEX Users: Send V1 tokens to the official V2 recovery address. - CEX Users: No further actions needed. **Q:** Dear $OPSEC Community, A few important updates about the $OPSEC V2 relaunch. Our team has been working tirelessly to ensure a smooth transition and to bring new benefits to our holders. Key Updates: 1) External V2 Contract Audit This Week: The new token contract is finalised and will undergo security audits by Hacken starting Wednesday. We expect the audits to be completed by Friday, allowing us to proceed with the relaunch shortly after. 2) Enhanced Features: The new contract will feature 0 buy and sell tax, increased liquidity, and improved security measures. These enhancements are designed to provide a better experience and greater value for all $OPSEC holders. 3) Token Migration Deadline for DEX & CEX holders 26/07/24 For those using DEX platforms (Trust Wallet, MetaMask, Uniswap, Ledger, Trezor, etc..), please send your V1 tokens to the official V2 recovery address: 0x362538c16a2868038AE72B608c080B6433f979C9 by 26/07/24. For CEX platform users (BingX, CoinEx), please await further instructions. We are coordinating with these exchanges to ensure a seamless transition. Practically: OpSec sends the V2 tokens and CEX's send V1 back. 4) Distribution Plan: Calculations and holders for V2 have been finalised. After thorough discussions, we have decided on a claim-based distribution method. This approach offers several advantages: - Reduces gas fees for the team, allowing us to reinvest those funds into the community. ⁃ Minimizes the risk of exploits and scams. - Spreads out trading pressure, cascading token buy / sell orders. - An eligibility form will be posted on CloudVerse, allowing users to check their claim status and ensure they receive their V2 tokens securely. CAUTION: We don't do airdrops! Recap: Action Needed - DEX Users: Send V1 tokens to the official V2 recovery address. - CEX Users: No further actions needed. Your CEX will take care of the V2 Migration. - Community Members: Stay engaged, spread the word, and help us build momentum. OpSec remained intact as the hacking attempt was countered by the team's swift response. Our goal is to expose the root findings and provide insights on how other projects can implement these security improvements, subject to a publishable article. We appreciate your continued support and patience as we finalise these crucial steps. The team is committed to transparency and security, and we will continue to provide regular updates. Thank you for being a part of the $OPSEC community and we look forward to executing V2 swiftly for everyone. Follow only official instructions and channels for all $OPSEC -related activities. Official links: - End of post, beware of scammers -

**Q:** Announcement: OPSEC Token Reimbursement Process Dear OPSEC Community, We want to clarify the reimbursement process for our OPSEC tokens and provide details on how different types of holders will be affected. This explanation will help you understand how we’re addressing the recent security incident and ensuring fair treatment for all token holders. With current models we ensure that the profits and losses are normalised in benefit to the long term holders of OpSec. Those who supported the migration will be benefited with a swifter and more secure process. More details below. 1. Overview of the Reimbursement Process We have implemented a reimbursement process to account for the value of your OPSEC tokens as of the critical snapshot period. This approach is designed to ensure fairness and consistency in the transition to our new V2 contract. Here’s a brief overview: Snapshot Blocks: - HBLOCK: Block 20276515 (The block immediately before the incident coined snapshot) - XBLOCK: Block 20277277 (The block when the announcement was made coined cut-off) 2. Holder Types and Their Reimbursement 1. Existing Holder (No Activity) Explanation: You held 11,169 tokens worth $5,567.88 and didn’t trade during the incident. You will receive the full value of your initial holdings, which remains $5,567.88. 2. Existing Holder Who Sold Activity: Sold 100 OPSEC for $16.89 Explanation: You had 3,000 tokens worth $1,495.53 but sold 100 tokens for $16.89. You’ll get back the initial value of $1,495.53, minus the $16.89 received from selling. Your final reimbursement will be $1,478.64. 3. Existing Holder Who Bought Activity: Bought 615.77 OPSEC for $73.50 Explanation: You had 8,240 tokens worth $410.79 and bought 615.77 more for $73.50. You will receive the value of your initial holdings ($410.79) plus the value of the new tokens at the HBLOCK price, totaling $484.29. 4. Holder Who Bought and Sold (Existing or New) Activity: Bought 4,046.80 OPSEC for $734.98 and sold 7,828.04 OPSEC for $1,451.68 Explanation: You initially had 3,911 tokens worth $1,949.92. You bought additional tokens and then sold a larger amount. You start with the initial value of $1,949.92, add the $734.98 spent, making $2,684.90, then subtract the $1,451.68 received from selling. Your final reimbursement value is $1,233.22. 5. Holder CEX We have the amount to send to each CEX which will be done separatly to the claim. Then the CEX will send out the tokens to each eligible holder, depending on the above criteria. 3. Benefits for Loyalists We want to acknowledge those who sent their tokens to the recovery address. Which was a critical part in our aim to secure liquidity, protecting the future value of the V2 token; enabling us to relaunch at 50m MC and increased liquidity stimulated by zero taxes. By sending your V1 tokens to the V2 recovery wallet, you helped ensure a smooth migration for our entire community. Here’s how this benefits you: - Enhanced Security: Tokens sent to the recovery address were accounted for with additional care, ensuring that they are securely included in the new V2 contract. - Fair Treatment: You will receive your tokens based on their value at the HBLOCK time, similar to other holders. - Continued Support: This process reflects our commitment to a secure and fair transition, ensuring that those who acted promptly are recognized. Thank you for your continued support and patience. We are working diligently to ensure a smooth and transparent transition to V2 tokens. Follow only official instructions and channels for all $OPSEC -related activities. Sincerely, OpSec Team Official Links: Website: Twitter: Discord: Telegram:

**A:** 1/2. Resignation Statement from Chris Williams, former CEO of OpSec. After considerable thought and with a heavy heart, I am announcing my resignation as CEO of OpSec, effective immediately. This decision has been incredibly difficult, and it is with deep regret that I must share that, along with me, the entire core team will also be stepping down. Despite our dedication and best efforts, we have encountered challenges that prevent us from continuing in a way that aligns with our values of transparency, accountability and integrity. This decision follows recent findings, highlighted by Zach XBT, along with our own assessment of OpSec’s operations. These revelations, coupled with the un-doxxed founder’s prolonged absence and sole control over the company’s finances, have severely limited our ability to lead and execute our vision effectively. Payment delays, layoffs and the lack of clarity regarding OpSec’s direction have placed a significant strain on our team and on our collective ability to deliver on the promises we made to you, our loyal community. When we started this journey with OpSec, the founder’s support energised us, and we made positive strides, building major partnerships, sponsoring events and generating huge momentum, hitting an ATH of over 300M MC. However, as market conditions changed, that level of support significantly shifted. Development slowed, partnerships stalled, and some core team members, unable to depend on reliable pay, had to leave or were simply discarded. Although significant revenues were collected, transparency and sufficient backing was missing, preventing us from making the meaningful progress we aimed to achieve. As professionals, we believe it is essential to operate within a framework of ethical accountability. Without clear financial backing and leadership, we found ourselves unable to uphold the transparency and accountability our community deserves. Communication became increasingly difficult, as we often had limited information to share despite repeatedly requesting updates from the founder. Although completely innocent of any wrong doing, the team have faced unwarranted aggression, unjustified attacks and threats and questions of our integrity from various angles, all whilst working hard to move OpSec forward. OpSec’s current structure lacks the foundational elements necessary for long-term success. The absence of transparent, accountable leadership, unresolved compliance issues, opaque decision making, along with recent internal and external discoveries have left us deeply concerned. As a team, we felt a duty of care to the community, which is why we prioritised a smooth relaunch. Although there were growing concerns about the project’s leadership, our immediate focus was on ensuring continuity and doing what we felt best for the community. 2/2. Since joining OpSec in February, I have invested my time, energy, and personal resources, even through serious spinal surgery. I have stood by the community through all the good and the bad times and have wanted nothing more than everyone to win, taking us where I truly believed was possible. I am a man of integrity and on October 1st, I stood before the community with genuine excitement about the future, having received approval for a game changing 30 day relaunch campaign prior. However, without the necessary financial support and company structural changes, our plans to execute a robust marketing campaign and successfully relaunch at full potential became impossible. In light of these circumstances, we have made the difficult decision to step away. OpSec, as it stands, is no longer viable, and we can’t with clear conscience continue to support it. Please understand, this decision has not been made lightly, as stepping away means leaving our positions and facing the uncertainty of unemployment. To the OpSec community, we know this news may be difficult to process, and for that, we sincerely apologise. This decision was the absolute last resort for us.
*— Chris*

In light of these circumstances, we have made the difficult decision to step away. OpSec, as it stands, is no longer viable, and we can’t with clear conscience continue to support it. Please understand, this decision has not been made lightly, as stepping away means leaving our positions and facing the uncertainty of unemployment. To the OpSec community, we know this news may be difficult to process, and for that, we sincerely apologise. This decision was the absolute last resort for us.
*— Chris*

**78.** 🚀 Development Updates! We're thrilled to share the latest progress on our development front as we continue enhancing and expanding the capabilities of our mainnet nodes, oneSec and CloudSec device. Our team has been working diligently to ensure we remain at the forefront of innovation and deliver alpha as we go to market. Here's an overview of what we've accomplished recently: 🔧 Mainnet Nodes Enhancements: - Added a feature that allows node owners to receive rewards, enhancing the value and utility of owning a node. - Finalised staking POC feature that enables users to earn nodes as rewards, further engaging our community. - Optimized database queries to improve performance and user experience across our platforms. 🖥️ User Interface and Experience: - Integrated Partial and Full nodes within the Marketplace page, providing a seamless experience for our users. - Implemented reflection/tax claim restriction to secure the reward system and maintain fairness in distribution. - Enhanced the dashboard with a new capacity bar and updated the treasury card to provide clearer financial insights. - Developed a new Validator UI complete with a reward claim button, making it easier for users to manage their contributions and rewards. - Custom backend application, Admin user functionality for customer support regarding node queries and bringing node logs to the UI. 💰 Reward System Enhancements: - Structured the rewards system to include tax rewards, reflection rewards (TBC), and validator rewards, each with specific attributes and retrieval methods. - Established a comprehensive API for accessing and managing these rewards. - Set up a robust system for claiming rewards through the UI, supported by a backend cron job that processes claims efficiently. 🌐 Project OneSec: - Nearing completion of all functions, with MVP on the horizon pending thorough testing. - Deployment of the website to IPFS, laying the groundwork for decentralized access. 🔧 CloudSec Device Development: - Stay tuned for updates coming up from box manufacturers in the coming days as we meet them in person this week! Please bear with us as we roll out these advancements live to our user base. As we continue to innovate and push the boundaries of what's possible, we remain committed to transparency and engagement with our community. Stay tuned for more updates, and thank you for being a vital part of our journey at OpSec!

**453.** The difference in returns after a Fed cut with a recession versus without a recession is negligible over 1-year, 3-year, and 5-year periods. While each rate cut comes under unique conditions, the overall trend is consistent: markets thrive on certainty. I believe the upcoming election and its potential turmoil will introduce more uncertainty to the market than a rate cut. The takeaway? Markets generally trend upward. However, yields on various financial instruments are likely to trend downward. This doesn't refer to staking yields, but rather yields on money market funds, treasuries, CDs, corporate bonds, municipal bonds, and savings accounts. Investors who gained exposure to these instruments when rates began to rise made a smart move, but yield-chasing investors missed out on significant gains in the stock market. The speed and extent of yield declines will depend on the rate of Fed cuts. The charts above suggest that the Fed might implement multiple cuts quickly. When rate cuts occur, the stock market's direction could influence the crypto market. This will be especially true if we enter a recession, which I expect to be relatively short-lived. In my opinion, conditions are set for crypto to finish this year explosively: - ETFs are trading strongly. - Wall Street is warming up to crypto. - The halving is behind us. - Inflation fears are subsiding. - One political party is considering a crypto pivot, while the other is heavily invested. - Strategic Bitcoin reserves are growing. - The money printer is ready to turn on. - Wire houses will finally unlock access to ETFs How could you not be bullish? Sure, uncertainties lie ahead, but if they play out favorably, significant moves are forming on the horizon. **457.** Announcement: OPSEC Token Reimbursement Process Dear OPSEC Community, We want to clarify the reimbursement process for our OPSEC tokens and provide details on how different types of holders will be affected. This explanation will help you understand how we’re addressing the recent security incident and ensuring fair treatment for all token holders. With current models we ensure that the profits and losses are normalised in benefit to the long term holders of OpSec. Those who supported the migration will be benefited with a swifter and more secure process. More details below. 1. Overview of the Reimbursement Process We have implemented a reimbursement process to account for the value of your OPSEC tokens as of the critical snapshot period. This approach is designed to ensure fairness and consistency in the transition to our new V2 contract. Here’s a brief overview: Snapshot Blocks: - HBLOCK: Block 20276515 (The block immediately before the incident coined snapshot) - XBLOCK: Block 20277277 (The block when the announcement was made coined cut-off) 2. Holder Types and Their Reimbursement 1. Existing Holder (No Activity) Explanation: You held 11,169 tokens worth $5,567.88 and didn’t trade during the incident. You will receive the full value of your initial holdings, which remains $5,567.88. 2. Existing Holder Who Sold Activity: Sold 100 OPSEC for $16.89 Explanation: You had 3,000 tokens worth $1,495.53 but sold 100 tokens for $16.89. You’ll get back the initial value of $1,495.53, minus the $16.89 received from selling. Your final reimbursement will be $1,478.64. 3. Existing Holder Who Bought Activity: Bought 615.77 OPSEC for $73.50 Explanation: You had 8,240 tokens worth $410.79 and bought 615.77 more for $73.50. You will receive the value of your initial holdings ($410.79) plus the value of the new tokens at the HBLOCK price, totaling $484.29. 4. Holder Who Bought and Sold (Existing or New) Activity: Bought 4,046.80 OPSEC for $734.98 and sold 7,828.04 OPSEC for $1,451.68 Explanation: You initially had 3,911 tokens worth $1,949.92. You bought additional tokens and then sold a larger amount. You start with the initial value of $1,949.92, add the $734.98 spent, making $2,684.90, then subtract the $1,451.68 received from selling. Your final reimbursement value is $1,233.22. 5. Holder CEX We have the amount to send to each CEX which will be done separatly to the claim. Then the CEX will send out the tokens to each eligible holder, depending on the above criteria. 3. Benefits for Loyalists We want to acknowledge those who sent their tokens to the recovery address. Which was a critical part in our aim to secure liquidity, protecting the future value of the V2 token; enabling us to relaunch at 50m MC and increased liquidity stimulated by zero taxes. By sending your V1 tokens to the V2 recovery wallet, you helped ensure a smooth migration for our entire community. Here’s how this benefits you: - Enhanced Security: Tokens sent to the recovery address were accounted for with additional care, ensuring that they are securely included in the new V2 contract. - Fair Treatment: You will receive your tokens based on their value at the HBLOCK time, similar to other holders. - Continued Support: This process reflects our commitment to a secure and fair transition, ensuring that those who acted promptly are recognized. Thank you for your continued support and patience. We are working diligently to ensure a smooth and transparent transition to V2 tokens. Follow only official instructions and channels for all $OPSEC -related activities. Sincerely, OpSec Team Official Links: Website: Twitter: Discord: Telegram:

**603.** 1/2. Resignation Statement from Chris Williams, former CEO of OpSec. After considerable thought and with a heavy heart, I am announcing my resignation as CEO of OpSec, effective immediately. This decision has been incredibly difficult, and it is with deep regret that I must share that, along with me, the entire core team will also be stepping down. Despite our dedication and best efforts, we have encountered challenges that prevent us from continuing in a way that aligns with our values of transparency, accountability and integrity. This decision follows recent findings, highlighted by Zach XBT, along with our own assessment of OpSec’s operations. These revelations, coupled with the un-doxxed founder’s prolonged absence and sole control over the company’s finances, have severely limited our ability to lead and execute our vision effectively. Payment delays, layoffs and the lack of clarity regarding OpSec’s direction have placed a significant strain on our team and on our collective ability to deliver on the promises we made to you, our loyal community. When we started this journey with OpSec, the founder’s support energised us, and we made positive strides, building major partnerships, sponsoring events and generating huge momentum, hitting an ATH of over 300M MC. However, as market conditions changed, that level of support significantly shifted. Development slowed, partnerships stalled, and some core team members, unable to depend on reliable pay, had to leave or were simply discarded. Although significant revenues were collected, transparency and sufficient backing was missing, preventing us from making the meaningful progress we aimed to achieve. As professionals, we believe it is essential to operate within a framework of ethical accountability. Without clear financial backing and leadership, we found ourselves unable to uphold the transparency and accountability our community deserves. Communication became increasingly difficult, as we often had limited information to share despite repeatedly requesting updates from the founder. Although completely innocent of any wrong doing, the team have faced unwarranted aggression, unjustified attacks and threats and questions of our integrity from various angles, all whilst working hard to move OpSec forward. OpSec’s current structure lacks the foundational elements necessary for long-term success. The absence of transparent, accountable leadership, unresolved compliance issues, opaque decision making, along with recent internal and external discoveries have left us deeply concerned. As a team, we felt a duty of care to the community, which is why we prioritised a smooth relaunch. Although there were growing concerns about the project’s leadership, our immediate focus was on ensuring continuity and doing what we felt best for the community. 2/2. Since joining OpSec in February, I have invested my time, energy, and personal resources, even through serious spinal surgery. I have stood by the community through all the good and the bad times and have wanted nothing more than everyone to win, taking us where I truly believed was possible. I am a man of integrity and on October 1st, I stood before the community with genuine excitement about the future, having received approval for a game changing 30 day relaunch campaign prior. However, without the necessary financial support and company structural changes, our plans to execute a robust marketing campaign and successfully relaunch at full potential became impossible. In light of these circumstances, we have made the difficult decision to step away. OpSec, as it stands, is no longer viable, and we can’t with clear conscience continue to support it. Please understand, this decision has not been made lightly, as stepping away means leaving our positions and facing the uncertainty of unemployment. To the OpSec community, we know this news may be difficult to process, and for that, we sincerely apologise. This decision was the absolute last resort for us.

**722.** The elegance of the Euler model is that it precisely tracks each user’s earned share of fees with minimal overhead, ensuring that “each liquidity provider is ensured that each transaction [they] can accurately obtain the benefits [they] deserve” . No more overpaying or underpaying rewards, and no more accumulating unclaimable tiny dust amounts – everything is accounted for to the last wei of ETH. It’s worth noting that Ethervista extended this concept not just to liquidity pools, but also to staking and locking features: the same Euler indexing is used to reward token stakers and even LP tokens that are locked up in special contracts (more on that shortly). The key takeaway is that fee-based yield in Ethervista is a first-class citizen, not an afterthought. This is a paradigm shift: instead of printing tokens to reward users, Ethervista bakes real revenue sharing into the AMM itself via code. It’s as if Uniswap’s 0.3% trading fee concept was turned into a full-fledged revenue distribution engine – except now all fees are in ETH, and parameters are much more flexible than the rigid Uniswap model.

**850.** New on NodeHub: Run Your Own Starknet RPC Node! We’re excited to announce that @Starknet Mainnet RPC nodes are now live on NodeHub! With just a few clicks, you can deploy your own private RPC endpoint, giving you faster, unrestricted access to Starknet’s Layer 2 network. What is Starknet? Starknet is a permissionless Layer 2 blockchain for Ethereum, leveraging advanced Validity-Rollup (ZK rollup) technology. Powered by STARK cryptographic proofs, it enables decentralized applications (dApps) to scale massively while maintaining Ethereum’s security and composability. Built using Cairo, a custom programming language optimized for zero-knowledge proofs, Starknet processes computation off-chain and posts verified state updates (called “state diffs”) to Ethereum mainnet. This approach delivers secure, high-performance, and low-cost transactions, making it ideal for developers building scalable dApps. Why run your own Starknet RPC node? The Starknet RPC API lets you retrieve chain state information and interact with the network — including posting transactions and estimating fees before sending them. By running your own node on NodeHub, you get: • Unrestricted access — no rate limits or shared bandwidth • Fast, low-latency connections for optimal performance • Full control over your node infrastructure and configuration Whether you’re building dApps, running bots, indexing data, or just want reliable direct access, spinning up your own Starknet RPC node puts you in control. - Vista (Euler) DEX vs Uni-style DEX 1. Revenue Model Uniswap and Other DEXs: - Liquidity providers (LPs) earn rewards from token inflation (e.g., $UNI ), which dilutes value over time. - Token creators must sell their holdings to profit, potentially causing sell pressure and harming token value. Ethervista: - Rewards LPs and token creators in ETH, a stable and high-value asset, avoiding token inflation. - Creators can set customizable protocol fees (e.g., $7 per swap), earning ETH directly without selling tokens, enabling sustainable monetization. - Locks liquidity for 5 days, reducing rug pull risks and offering long-term trust mechanisms. 2. Community Incentives Uniswap: - Focuses on short-term liquidity with no emphasis on community building. - Lacks mechanisms to engage and reward users for long-term participation. Ethervista: - Incentivizes community-driven growth with ETH rewards for LPs and stakers. - Encourages LP locking, creating a virtuous cycle: Locked liquidity → Higher user trust → Increased trading volume → More ETH rewards.

**116.** Vista (Euler) DEX vs Uni-style DEX 1. Revenue Model Uniswap and Other DEXs: - Liquidity providers (LPs) earn rewards from token inflation (e.g., $UNI ), which dilutes value over time. - Token creators must sell their holdings to profit, potentially causing sell pressure and harming token value. Ethervista: - Rewards LPs and token creators in ETH, a stable and high-value asset, avoiding token inflation. - Creators can set customizable protocol fees (e.g., $7 per swap), earning ETH directly without selling tokens, enabling sustainable monetization. - Locks liquidity for 5 days, reducing rug pull risks and offering long-term trust mechanisms. 2. Community Incentives Uniswap: - Focuses on short-term liquidity with no emphasis on community building. - Lacks mechanisms to engage and reward users for long-term participation. Ethervista: - Incentivizes community-driven growth with ETH rewards for LPs and stakers. - Encourages LP locking, creating a virtuous cycle: Locked liquidity → Higher user trust → Increased trading volume → More ETH rewards.

**47.** Breaks the Ponzi script: No “number go up” loop that only works if new buyers subsidize old ones. Rewards don’t depend on fresh exit liquidity. Sustainable rewards model: Yield is tied to real activity (part of the tx fees), not emissions that decay to zero. If activity stalls, rewards adjust; if activity grows, holders benefit. Simple, honest. Fully circulating / transparent supply mechanics: No surprise unlocks, no mystery treasuries silently dripping on you. Supply policy is legible on-chain. Alignment by design: Users, LPs, and long-term holders earn from the same economic engine. Not three games at war with each other. Anti-mercenary tokenomics: Instead of bribing for short-lived TVL, it optimizes for stickiness and repeat usage. Incentives were built to survive bear phases, not just headline weeks.

**156.** O cooperativismo moderno — Elinor Ostrom & Yochai Benkler A ganhadora do Prêmio Nobel Elinor Ostrom (1990) provou que comunidades são capazes de administrar recursos coletivos com eficiência, sem depender de hierarquias ou corporações. Já Yochai Benkler, em “The Wealth of Networks” (2006), mostrou como a produção colaborativa e descentralizada cria riqueza social e tecnológica. A EtherVista reflete esses princípios: “A verdadeira descentralização começa quando cada voz é ouvida.” Cada swap, cada stake, cada contribuição é uma prova de que cooperar é mais poderoso do que competir.

**Q:** Any solution to this?
**A:** This is an answer from RNG on Discord that is handy for some node related questions: Current networks are on testnet. If networks allocate, you will receive rewards. However, we are working with more networks, and once they are integrated, they will provide exclusive supply just for Cloudverse node runners. Those earnings will be displayed in Cloudverse. The second type of earning is random and isn't dependent on us. If a token decides to airdrop to node runners themselves (without direct contact with us), you will receive rewards that way too! It's a usual way for testnet networks to allocate rewards for all the node runners, as they are fully dependent on contributors like them. Cloudverse is still in Epoch 1; this is just the beginning of what is yet to come, including more mainnet networks and exclusive supply.
*— Satori Tendou*

**Q:** /opsec is opsec a layer 1 blockchain?
**A:** I understand its also a modular blockchain. Modular Architecture: OpSec Network uses a modular architecture approach which allows for flexibility, scalability, and interoperability. Phase 5 roadmap: - Cross-chain Focus and Development of OpSec Network (L1 Modular Blockchain): Working on interoperability to smoothly connect with other blockchains. - OpSec Network (L1) Testnet Launch: Launching a testnet for our blockchain, inviting feedback and testing from the community. - OpSec (L1) Mainnet Launch: Fully launching our blockchain, ensuring it's secure and ready for wide use.

**Q:** People are getting more articulate. So I have did my best to provide a articulate response. I thank you all for the hard work and supporting the narrative of the so much disputed "soon". Here below my response to OttoToot: I had a long call with HR about this very exact matter. So as I explained, in a few weeks we have much better capacity to handle the demand. Now getting back to the capacity ceiling; The rise in interest only started to peak since a month, not since January, as we only launched since beginning of March. 5-6 weeks to be exact. You cant build a team before but after the estimated demand. Especially not if you cant predict the interest. Yet we do what we can with what we have. Now, more transparently, our HR is scouting to grow the team of tech support, but you need to understand that talent is always scarce. And more scarcer when the industry scales rapidly. Fact remains that the platform is working and running, yet we are subject to the progress of the network partners. We know that the lightnodes of avail are not shown on the Telemetry. And as we said previously the onchain referencing and data is "soon" to be upgraded on the UI. **Q:** ✅ Engaging the Community During Quiet Moments #1 As community moderators, it’s essential to keep engagement high, especially during challenging market conditions. Here are some ways to interact and keep the community active: 1. Send a welcome message: When there is a new member, send out a welcoming message.❗️This message should include links to project documents and information about ongoing campaigns/upcoming events, helping new members feel informed and integrated into the community. 2. Spark conversations with a question: Post thought-provoking or fun questions daily to spark conversation. Examples: "If you could decentralize any aspect of your daily life, what would it be?" "If OpSec could partner with any tech company, who would you choose and why?" "What futuristic feature do you hope to see in the OpSec network?" "What are the biggest advantages you've found using decentralized cloud services?" "How do you think decentralized networks will evolve in the next five years?" "What was your experience setting up a node with OpSec’s one-click deployment?" 3. Share news and updates Share relevant news updates related to the community, such as recent developments on Twitter or significant crypto news. Encourage conversation around these updates to keep members informed and engaged. 4. Rewards system reminders Regularly remind members of the rewards system in place, such as upcoming staking or Zealy campaign. Highlighting these opportunities can motivate members to stay active and participate more in the community.
**A:** @Zenkin_CaprisLeeO @Zenkin_Robin @Zenkin_Ame @Zenkin_Satori

**Q:** ✅ Engaging the Community During Quiet Moments #2 5. Feedback on new features: Ask members to provide feedback on new features or services (for example OneSec beta). This shows that their opinions are valued and can help improve the community’s offerings.❗️Collect the feedback to the debrief channel so that we can share it with the team. 6. Suggestions for improvement: Ask members for suggestions on how to improve the community. This encourages members to think critically about the community’s development and fosters a sense of ownership and participation. ❗️Collect to the debrief channel. 7. Information recap: Gather and share recent news or posts relevant to the project. Providing a recap of important information helps ensure that all members are up-to-date and can foster discussions around these updates. Don’t copy-paste or forward chunks of content. Endeavour to add a human touch such as an intro to news/updates, a question or a simple summary in your own words. 8. Use alt accounts: Use an alternate account to help drive conversations and keep discussions lively.

**Q:** Announcement: OPSEC Token Reimbursement Process Dear OPSEC Community, We want to clarify the reimbursement process for our OPSEC tokens and provide details on how different types of holders will be affected. This explanation will help you understand how we’re addressing the recent security incident and ensuring fair treatment for all token holders. With current models we ensure that the profits and lossess are normalised in benefit to the long term holders of $OPSEC . Those who supported the migration will enjoy a swifter and more secure process. More details below. Note: Those who have send their tokens after buying $OPSEC beyond the XBLOCK (Cut-off) will also be reimbursed. 1. Overview of the Reimbursement Process We have implemented a reimbursement process to account for the value of your OPSEC tokens as of the critical snapshot period. This approach is designed to ensure fairness and consistency in the transition to our new V2 contract. Here’s a brief overview: Snapshot Blocks: - HBLOCK: Block 20276515 (The block immediately before the incident) - XBLOCK: Block 20277277 (The block when the announcement was made) HBLOCK Equivalent: The value of your tokens calculated based on their worth at the HBLOCK time. This ensures that any trading activity during the incident period is factored into the reimbursement. 2. Holder Types and Their Reimbursement 1. Existing Holder (No Activity) Explanation: You held 11,169 tokens worth $5,567.88 and didn’t trade during the incident. **A:** V2 Transparency report : What exactly happened during the attack of 10th of July and how was it controlled? In line with our commitment to full transparency, we wanted to provide an update on the recent staking incident. An internal developer turned rogue and managed to exploit an existing access method. Here’s a breakdown of how it occurred: - A developer with internal access waited until a private key was utilized on our server. Despite resetting passwords to the server being utilized, they retained access from a previous session using a command-line tool called tmux, which keeps ssh sessions open. - They made a mistake by running the second server used to execute the attack using our account provider, which gave us the ability to analyze how the attack was performed and by who. - With this server, they used a script to extract the private key as it was used, However, this exposed both their Git username and IP address, which was another mistake on their part. - The IP address used matched the one from the tmux session, providing clear evidence of their involvement. No one else accessed the server during the hack. - The rest of the actions taken by the attacker, as well as our full response, have been explained here. All the evidence has been gathered and is under forensic analysis. The person responsible has been removed, reported, and may be publicly exposed after further investigation.
*— Gino I we never use DM first*

**Q:** Okay Sir! Can we even leave the group?
**A:** 1/2. Resignation Statement from Chris Williams, former CEO of OpSec. After considerable thought and with a heavy heart, I am announcing my resignation as CEO of OpSec, effective immediately. This decision has been incredibly difficult, and it is with deep regret that I must share that, along with me, the entire core team will also be stepping down. Despite our dedication and best efforts, we have encountered challenges that prevent us from continuing in a way that aligns with our values of transparency, accountability and integrity. This decision follows recent findings, highlighted by Zach XBT, along with our own assessment of OpSec’s operations. These revelations, coupled with the un-doxxed founder’s prolonged absence and sole control over the company’s finances, have severely limited our ability to lead and execute our vision effectively. Payment delays, layoffs and the lack of clarity regarding OpSec’s direction have placed a significant strain on our team and on our collective ability to deliver on the promises we made to you, our loyal community. When we started this journey with OpSec, the founder’s support energised us, and we made positive strides, building major partnerships, sponsoring events and generating huge momentum, hitting an ATH of over 300M MC. However, as market conditions changed, that level of support significantly shifted. Development slowed, partnerships stalled, and some core team members, unable to depend on reliable pay, had to leave or were simply discarded. Although significant revenues were collected, transparency and sufficient backing was missing, preventing us from making the meaningful progress we aimed to achieve. As professionals, we believe it is essential to operate within a framework of ethical accountability. Without clear financial backing and leadership, we found ourselves unable to uphold the transparency and accountability our community deserves. **315.** The role of lending in a DAO is to provide a mechanism for members of the organization to borrow and lend funds without the need for intermediaries such as banks or traditional financial institutions. Lending in a DAO allows participants to access capital for various purposes, such as investment, business expansion, or personal needs. Lending in a DAO is typically facilitated through smart contracts, which are self-executing agreements with the terms of the loan encoded into the blockchain. These smart contracts ensure transparency, immutability, and automation of the lending process, eliminating the need for trust in centralized entities. The lending activities in a DAO can be carried out in various ways, such as peer-to-peer lending, where members lend directly to each other, or through liquidity pools where participants contribute funds that can be borrowed by others. The terms of the loans, including interest rates, repayment schedules, and collateral requirements, are determined by the rules and governance mechanisms of the DAO. By enabling lending within a DAO, participants can benefit from lower costs, faster transactions, and increased accessibility compared to traditional lending systems. It also allows for greater financial inclusion, as individuals who may not have access to traditional banking services can participate in lending activities within the DAO. Overall, lending plays a crucial role in a DAO by providing a decentralized and efficient way for members to access and deploy capital within the organization's ecosystem.

It's important because it allows participants to access capital for various purposes, like investing, expanding businesses, or personal needs, all within the decentralized ecosystem of the DAO. Novice: That sounds interesting, but how does lending actually work in a DAO? Do we need intermediaries? Savvy Cryptonative: No, that's the beauty of it! Lending in a DAO is facilitated through smart contracts, which are self-executing agreements stored on the blockchain. These smart contracts ensure transparency, immutability, and automation of the lending process. So, there's no need for intermediaries like banks. Everything is transparent and executed automatically. Novice: That sounds really efficient! But how do people lend and borrow from each other in a DAO? **430.** Memes and GIFs: Use trending memes or create your own to explain complex web3 concepts in a fun and relatable way. Story Threads: Create a Twitter thread that tells a story related to your project. It could be a fictional use case, a day in the life of a user, or even a historical parallel. Interactive Polls: Run polls asking users about their web3 experiences, preferences, or predictions. This not only engages your audience but also provides you with valuable insights. Challenges: Start a challenge related to your project. For example, "Share your most unique use case for our platform and win XYZ tokens!" Art and Music: Collaborate with digital artists or musicians to create art or music inspired by your project. Share these creations and tag the creators. Web3 Analogies: Draw parallels between everyday life and web3 concepts. For instance, "If Bitcoin is digital gold, our project is the digital [something relatable]." Behind-the-Scenes: Share candid moments from your team's brainstorming sessions, coding marathons, or even casual hangouts. It humanizes your project and builds trust. Trivia and Quizzes: Post interesting facts or quizzes about your project or the broader web3 space. Reward participants with tokens or other incentives. AR Filters: Create augmented reality filters related to your project. Encourage followers to use them and share their experiences. Countdowns: If you're launching a new feature or update, create a countdown series with hints or teasers leading up to the big reveal. Collaborative Storytelling: Start a story about your project and ask followers to continue it in the replies. This can lead to some fun and unexpected narratives. Web3 Haikus: Challenge your community to describe your project or a web3 concept in a haiku. Virtual Scavenger Hunts: Hide clues or codes in your website or platform and create a scavenger hunt. Winners could get early access, tokens, or other rewards. Personal Anecdotes: Share personal stories of how the project has impacted you or your team. Authenticity goes a long way. Pop Culture References: Relate your project to popular movies, TV shows, or books. For example, "If our platform was in the Game of Thrones universe, it would be [XYZ]."

Twitter Spaces: Host impromptu "mystery guest" sessions on Twitter Spaces where participants can guess the identity of the guest related to the web3 world. Web3 Fashion: Design virtual wearables or accessories inspired by your project and showcase them in virtual fashion shows. Recipe Analogies: Compare your project to a recipe. "Our platform is like a pizza, where [feature] is the cheese, [feature] is the crust..." Virtual Escape Rooms: Design a web3-themed escape room challenge. Participants have to solve puzzles related to your project to "escape." Web3 Parodies: Create parodies of popular songs, replacing lyrics with references to your project or the web3 space. Interactive Fiction: Use tools like Twine to create an interactive story where choices lead to different outcomes related to your project. Web3 Horoscopes: Share daily or weekly horoscopes with predictions based on blockchain movements or your project's milestones. "Caption This" Contests: Post an intriguing image related to your project and ask followers to come up with a caption. Web3 ASMR: Record ASMR videos of blockchain transactions, coding sessions, or other project-related sounds. "In Another Universe": Describe what your project would look like in different fictional universes, e.g., "In the Star Wars universe, our platform would be..." Web3 Yoga: Design a yoga sequence inspired by blockchain processes or your project's journey. Web3 Bedtime Stories: Create and share bedtime stories where your project is the central theme or hero. Blockchain Mysteries: Share mysterious or unexplained events from the blockchain world and relate them to your project. Web3 Dance Challenges: Choreograph a dance that represents your project's features or benefits and challenge the community to replicate or improve upon it. "What's in the Box?": Post a picture of a box or package and let users guess what's inside related to your project. Reveal the answer later with a fun twist. Web3 Mad Libs: Create a story template with blanks and ask your followers to fill in the gaps using web3 terminology. Blockchain Pranks: Share light-hearted pranks or jokes (make sure they're in good taste) related to web3, ensuring they're fun and not misleading. Web3 DIY: Share DIY crafts or projects inspired by your platform, like making physical tokens, themed decorations, or even baked goods. "Swap Roles" Day: Let a community member take over your Twitter for a day, sharing their perspective on your project. The key is to think outside the box, engage with your audience in fresh ways, and always ensure that your content aligns with your project's values and goals.

Code ASMR: Share videos of you typing code, the hum of a server room, or other developer-related sounds. "Dev Diary": Share short, candid videos or threads about your day-to-day life as a developer, including both successes and failures. "If This Was Code": Take popular movies, books, or events and describe them as if they were coded. E.g., "If Romeo and Juliet were a JavaScript function..." Meme Debugging: Share a piece of code and ask followers to spot the bug using only meme responses. Code Art: Use platforms like p5.js to create visual art or animations through code and share the results. "Back in My Day": Share old code or tech and reminisce about "the good old days" of development. It's a fun way to see how far tech has come. "Code Karaoke": Rewrite popular song lyrics to be about coding or tech topics. Emoji Code: Write code using only emojis and challenge others to decipher it. "What's This Tool?": Share obscure or old tools and ask followers to guess their purpose. "Dev Confessions": Share funny or embarrassing mistakes you've made in your coding journey and encourage others to do the same. Code in Unusual Places: Share pictures of you coding in unconventional locations, like on a mountain top, in a boat, or in a treehouse. "Swap Projects" Day: Exchange projects with another developer for a day and share your experiences working on something entirely new. "Code Recipes": Describe coding tasks or projects as if they were cooking recipes. "Code Theater": Act out a piece of code or a dev scenario with friends, using props, costumes, and drama.

**653.** Zenkin CM Guidelines 1️⃣ Everyone is expected to work from a laptop - Except in special (and hopefully short/rare) circumstances. 2️⃣ Everyone is expected to be flexible with tasks. - If the team asks for an announcement to be posted, a bot command to be updated, an AMA to be hosted, we should generally oblige (within reason). 3️⃣ Communicate absences. - If you’re ill, have a family emergency, or otherwise won’t be available during your regular shift, you really need to advise the team as far in advance as you can. We will try to accommodate the coverage, but it can be know only if we know about it. 4️⃣ Treat all community members with patience and respect. ❗️ - Helping the community is our primary function as mods. If we’re short, unhelpful, or unkind, we’ve failed our most basic mission and we risk repercussions from our clients. Maintaining politeness with community members, even in the face of stubbornness or repeated misunderstandings, is essential for moderators to foster a welcoming and supportive environment. This approach not only reflects positively on the community's culture but also facilitates constructive dialogue and mutual respect. 5️⃣ Think for ourselves and help guide our clients. - If a client releases an announcement or article that is unclear, it is incumbent upon us to say something about it to the team. Having clear lines of communication makes us better mods, and the project will appreciate us going the extra mile to help them. 6️⃣ We are a team, don’t hesitate to convey feedback to another person in case you notice a mistake. - Ensure you are open to feedback and constant improvement. We are all working towards the same goal of expanding Zenkin, thus proactvity and sharing feedback is well seen.

**859.** Our platform facilitates the deployment and management of nodes across various blockchain networks. These nodes generate rewards through a range of mechanisms such as APY, airdrops, transaction fees (shared), staking rewards, network fees (shared), NFTs, Governance, Block rewards, claims etc. Whatever the deployed node offers on their side, we are enhancing the UI/UX by providing dynamic lists of available rewards for each deployed node, making it easier for users to track their earnings. On top of this migration to L1 we can amplify this via our own incentives to holders. Now imagine staking on top of this with one click miners + GPU owners (both earn passive rewards). By expanding our partnerships, we plan to support nodes across multiple chains, prioritizing those with the most lucrative incentives, the community here spoke and we listened during test phase, so things round here are going to hot up significantly. I want to see everyone here a multi node runner on xx+ chains earning mulitple rewards in the next month or so. We’re making it happen. Ideas are nothing, execution is the game. Seeing questions like this is proof we’re still early in the education phase as the paradigm shift to mainstream adoption for the global market continues. Now you’ll see web2 cloud giants realising IAAS is the next revo. Seeing your friends and family use thus with a couple clicks compared to needing engineering / CLI / Compsci knowledge, solo management, costly maintenance etc is the execution part. No one wants to hit net loss spending more money running server’s than reward profits generated. Testnet is the stepping point for these late bloomers, that's why we worship it in exchange. This is when we see the demand and volume go parabolic. Should also have oneSec dapp released soon that again opens our audience to mass market x2.

**1009.** Static websites, while simpler in architecture, can still be quite complex in terms of the content and functionality they deliver. They can include videos, animations, and interactive elements achieved through client-side technologies. Dynamic websites, on the other hand, are more complex overall due to their server-side processing and ability to deliver personalized, real-time content. Static websites are best for content that doesn’t change frequently, such as blogs, portfolios, or marketing sites. Dynamic websites are better suited for applications requiring real-time user interaction, such as social media platforms, e-commerce sites, and web applications. Both types can be deployed on platforms like IPFS, with static websites being directly hosted and dynamic websites leveraging additional technologies like APIs and smart contracts for their interactive components.

"What was your experience setting up a node with OpSec’s one-click deployment?" 3. Share news and updates Share relevant news updates related to the community, such as recent developments on Twitter or significant crypto news. Encourage conversation around these updates to keep members informed and engaged. 4. Rewards system reminders Regularly remind members of the rewards system in place, such as upcoming staking or Zealy campaign. Highlighting these opportunities can motivate members to stay active and participate more in the community.
