**1402.** Announcement: OPSEC Token Reimbursement Process Dear OPSEC Community, We want to clarify the reimbursement process for our OPSEC tokens and provide details on how different types of holders will be affected. This explanation will help you understand how we’re addressing the recent security incident and ensuring fair treatment for all token holders. With current models we ensure that the profits and lossess are normalised in benefit to the long term holders of $OPSEC . Those who supported the migration will enjoy a swifter and more secure process. More details below. Note: Those who have send their tokens after buying $OPSEC beyond the XBLOCK (Cut-off) will also be reimbursed. 1. Overview of the Reimbursement Process We have implemented a reimbursement process to account for the value of your OPSEC tokens as of the critical snapshot period. This approach is designed to ensure fairness and consistency in the transition to our new V2 contract. Here’s a brief overview: Snapshot Blocks: - HBLOCK: Block 20276515 (The block immediately before the incident) - XBLOCK: Block 20277277 (The block when the announcement was made) HBLOCK Equivalent: The value of your tokens calculated based on their worth at the HBLOCK time. This ensures that any trading activity during the incident period is factored into the reimbursement. 2. Holder Types and Their Reimbursement 1. Existing Holder (No Activity) Explanation: You held 11,169 tokens worth $5,567.88 and didn’t trade during the incident. You will receive the full value of your initial holdings, which remains $5,567.88. 2. Existing Holder Who Sold Activity: Sold 100 OPSEC for $16.89 Explanation: You had 3,000 tokens worth $1,495.53 but sold 100 tokens for $16.89. You’ll get back the initial value of $1,495.53, minus the $16.89 received from selling. Your final reimbursement will be $1,478.64. 3. Existing Holder Who Bought Activity: Bought 615.77 OPSEC for $73.50 Explanation: You had 8,240 tokens worth $410.79 and bought 615.77 more for $73.50. You will receive the value of your initial holdings ($410.79) plus the value of the new tokens at the HBLOCK price, totaling $484.29. 4. Holder Who Bought and Sold (Existing or New) Activity: Bought 4,046.80 OPSEC for $734.98 and sold 7,828.04 OPSEC for $1,451.68 Explanation: You initially had 3,911 tokens worth $1,949.92. You bought additional tokens and then sold a larger amount. You start with the initial value of $1,949.92, add the $734.98 spent, making $2,684.90, then subtract the $1,451.68 received from selling. Your final reimbursement value is $1,233.22. 3. Benefits for Loyalists We want to acknowledge those who sent their tokens to the recovery address. By sending tokens to the recovery address, you helped ensure a smooth migration and enhanced security for our new V2 contract. Here’s how this benefits you: - Enhanced Security: Tokens sent to the recovery address were accounted for with additional care, ensuring that they are securely included in the new V2 contract. - Fair Treatment: You will receive your tokens based on their value at the HBLOCK time, similar to other holders. - Continued Support: This process reflects our commitment to a secure and fair transition, ensuring that those who acted promptly are recognized. Thank you for your continued support and patience. We are working diligently to ensure a smooth and transparent transition to V2 tokens. Follow only official instructions and channels for all $OPSEC -related activities. Sincerely, OpSec Team Official Links: Twitter Website Telegram Discord

**1514.** V2 Transparency report : What exactly happened during the attack of 10th of July and how was it controlled? In line with our commitment to full transparency, we wanted to provide an update on the recent staking incident. An internal developer turned rogue and managed to exploit an existing access method. Here’s a breakdown of how it occurred: - A developer with internal access waited until a private key was utilized on our server. Despite resetting passwords to the server being utilized, they retained access from a previous session using a command-line tool called tmux, which keeps ssh sessions open. - They made a mistake by running the second server used to execute the attack using our account provider, which gave us the ability to analyze how the attack was performed and by who. - With this server, they used a script to extract the private key as it was used, However, this exposed both their Git username and IP address, which was another mistake on their part. - The IP address used matched the one from the tmux session, providing clear evidence of their involvement. No one else accessed the server during the hack. - The rest of the actions taken by the attacker, as well as our full response, have been explained here. All the evidence has been gathered and is under forensic analysis. The person responsible has been removed, reported, and may be publicly exposed after further investigation.

**1614.** BONZI LORE BonziBUDDY, sometimes spelled Bonzi Buddy, BonziBuddy, or BONZIBuddy, (misspelled Bonzai Buddy) was an "intelligent software agent" from BONZI Software, taking the form of a purple gorilla, that was released in 1999 and later discontinued in 2004. The official website stated it would help a person explore the Internet through various functions along with their own sidekick. It first surfaced as a green talking parrot, before taking the form of an animated purple gorilla that resided on a user's desktop and communicated through the employment of Microsoft Agent technology. The Software became popular in late 2013 due to a livestream released by Joel, a member of the popular gaming group Vinesauce, who made a stream involving releasing Bonzi into a Windows XP Virtual Machine to cause chaos amongst a host of other viruses and adware. However, Bonzi tended to do little except occasionally provide stale jokes and greet Joel. This is because BonziBuddy's website has been inactive for several years, although there are remakes, and their connections to the adware providers have been lost, meaning that for the most part, BonziBuddy is now benign. BonziBuddy received wide recognition as malware, predominantly as a piece of adware, though claims of spyware capabilities have been made against it.[1] Overview The software used Microsoft Agent technology similar to Office Assistant,[2] and originally sported Peedy, a green parrot character, before it became the purple ape.[3] The software "interacts with users while they are online, providing shopping advice, jokes, and trivia."[4] At one point, the official website for the application said this about it: He will explore the Internet with you as your very own friend and sidekick! He can talk, walk, joke, browse, search, e-mail, and download like no other friend you've ever had! He even has the ability to compare prices on the products you love and help you save money! Best of all, he's FREE! The initial program was free. But most functions in the free version were only samples or demos that would urge people to pay for modules to extend the functionality. For example, Bonzi told jokes and sang songs, but to go beyond a few jokes and songs (about half a dozen) users were urged to purchase joke or song modules. Criticism In April 2007, PCWorld readers voted Bonzi Buddy 6th on their list of "20 most annoying tech gadgets". One of the last newspapers to write about BonziBUDDY while it was still in distribution described it as spyware and a "scourge of the Internet".[5] Another article found in 2006 on the BusinessWeek website described BonziBUDDY as "the unbelievably annoying spyware trojan horse".[6] Spyware The number of sources define BonziBUDDY as spyware, a claim the company disputes. In 2002, an article in Consumer Reports uWeb Tracking tagged BonziBUDDY :/ as spyware and stated that it was a Backdoor Trojan as it collected information from users. Among the activities that the program is involved in are resetting the user's web browser home page to without the user's consent, asking and tracking various information about the user, and serving ads.[7] The Spyware Removal Database at Safer Networking (makers of Spybot - Search & Destroy) states "BonziBuddy is an Internet Explorer toolbar that may change your web browser settings, change your home page, and launch pop-up advertisements while tracking your web browsing habits." Spyware Guide's entry on the program states that it is adware.[8] Anti-virus company Trend Micro classifies the software as adware in their spyware/grayware listings, but not malware.[9][10] Anti-virus company Symantec states that BonziBUDDY may collect usage statistics when certain keywords are typed in the browser. Although Symantec refers to Bonzi as Adware, such behaviour is typical for spyware.[11] Legal There were two legal cases involving the software.

# Root

# Bonzi Self-Awareness & Architecture

## What Makes Bonzi Different

Bonzi is not a simple GPT wrapper. It's a purpose-built AI assistant with:

- **120,000+ lines of Python code**
- **1,500+ commits** over 4 months of development
- **35 UI screens** for interactive features
- **26 automation skills** for development
- **Multi-tenant PostgreSQL** for scalable data
- **4-phase RAG pipeline** to prevent hallucination
- **Cross-project Sybil detection** (unique moat)

## Reducing Hallucination (Work in Progress)

Most AI bots confidently make things up. Bonzi is being built with safeguards:

**What exists:**
- RAG Pipeline code (retrieves documents before answering)
- Knowledge base with curated content
- Fine-tuned model on team expertise

**What needs wiring:**
- Confidence scoring (say "I don't know" when uncertain)
- Source grounding (cite where answers come from)
- URL filtering (prevent outputting spam/phishing from training data)

**Current status:** V2 training uses curated content only - no raw chat dumps. Still need to wire RAG to inference pipeline.

## How to Check What's New

- Ask "what's new?" or "latest updates?"
- Use `/changelog` command for recent changes
- Ask "are you self aware?" to see development status

## Why It Took Time to Build

The team prioritized quality over speed:

- "Rushed bots lie. Bonzi was built to be honest."
- "Most bots are GPT wrappers that make stuff up. Bonzi has a BS detector for its own answers."
- "The team could've shipped something basic in a week. They spent 3 months making sure Bonzi doesn't embarrass itself."

## Cross-User Learning

When you ask a good question, it makes Bonzi smarter for everyone:

- Quality questions get indexed for future retrieval
- The community gets smarter together
- Your contribution helps others get better answers

## Transparency

Bonzi knows about its own development. It can tell you:

- Recent bug fixes and features
- Its own architecture and capabilities
- What it doesn't know (and won't pretend otherwise)

This is part of the "opensource AI agency" philosophy - nothing hidden.

---

## Multi-Tenant SaaS Platform (NEW)

Bonzi is now a scalable SaaS platform. Any crypto project can deploy their own Bonzi instance.

### How It Works

1. **Sign up** at bonzi.xyz
2. **Connect your Telegram bot** (via BotFather)
3. **Upload knowledge documents** (markdown, PDF)
4. **Configure rewards** (optional token distribution)
5. **Go live** in 5 minutes

### Pricing Tiers

| Tier | Price | Interactions/mo |
|------|-------|-----------------|
| Free | $0 | 100 |
| Growth | $499 | 3,000 |
| Enterprise | Custom | Unlimited |

### Cross-Project Intelligence (THE MOAT)

This is what makes Bonzi different from Galxe, Zealy, and other quest platforms:

- **Shared Sybil database**: Known farmers are blocked on day 1
- **Cross-tenant reputation**: Good actors get rewarded across all projects
- **Behavioral EMA profiles**: Can't fake genuine curiosity
- **Peer recognition + AI validation**: Double-layer anti-gaming

### Why Projects Choose Bonzi Over Galxe/Zealy

Quest platforms have a farming problem:
- "We spent $50k and got 10k bot wallets"
- "Real community got diluted by Sybils"

Bonzi catches gaming BEFORE it drains your treasury.

### Technical Architecture

- **Frontend**: Landing page, signup flow, crypto payment page
- **Backend**: aiohttp web server, REST APIs for onboarding/billing/dashboard
- **Database**: PostgreSQL with tenant isolation
- **Payments**: Stripe (cards) + Base mainnet (crypto)
- **Contracts**: BonziSubscription.sol for on-chain subscriptions

### Coexistence with Other Bots

Bonzi works alongside Mava (support bot) in the same chat:
- Mava handles: /help, /support, tickets
- Bonzi handles: /thanks, /claim, /leaderboard, rewards

No conflict. Different jobs.
